name: Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita
description: Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita (AMC) describes a condition characterized by multiple joint contractures present at birth. It is not a specific diagnosis but rather a descriptive term encompassing a variety of underlying conditions that limit fetal movement in the womb. These contractures can affect any joint but commonly involve the hands, wrists, elbows, shoulders, hips, knees, and feet. The severity and specific joints affected vary widely among individuals with AMC.
inheritance: Varies depending on the underlying cause; can be autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, X-linked, or sporadic.
symptoms: Dimpling of the skin over joints
prognosis: The prognosis varies widely depending on the underlying cause and the severity of the contractures. Many individuals with AMC can achieve significant functional improvement with appropriate treatment and therapy. Some may have lifelong limitations.
lifeExpectancy: Life expectancy is generally normal, unless the underlying condition involves severe respiratory or neurological complications.
diagnosticMethods: Genetic testing (whole exome sequencing, chromosomal microarray)
eli5Summary: Imagine a baby born with stiff joints that don't bend easily. That's like Arthrogryposis. It happens when the baby doesn't move enough inside mommy's tummy. Doctors and therapists help them stretch and move so they can play and grow stronger.
clinicalSummary: Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita (AMC) is a heterogeneous group of conditions characterized by congenital joint contractures affecting two or more body areas. The underlying etiology is diverse, encompassing genetic factors (mutations in genes involved in muscle development, neuronal function, or connective tissue synthesis), environmental factors (oligohydramnios, maternal illness), and neuromuscular disorders. Pathologically, AMC results from decreased or absent fetal movement during gestation, leading to abnormal joint and muscle development. Clinical presentation varies widely, ranging from mild contractures treatable with conservative measures to severe, debilitating deformities requiring extensive surgical intervention. Diagnosis involves clinical evaluation, imaging studies, and genetic testing to identify the underlying cause. Management focuses on improving joint mobility, preventing further deformities, and maximizing functional independence through physical therapy, occupational therapy, serial casting, bracing, and surgical correction.
historicalBackground: Descriptions of congenital contractures date back to ancient times. However, the term 'Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita' was formally introduced in the medical literature in the 20th century to describe the constellation of findings associated with multiple congenital joint contractures.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Identification of Novel Genes Associated with Distal Arthrogryposis
recentBreakthroughs.description: Recent research has identified new genes associated with distal arthrogryposis, expanding our understanding of the genetic basis of these conditions and improving diagnostic capabilities.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Advancements in Prenatal Diagnosis of Arthrogryposis
recentBreakthroughs.description: Improved prenatal diagnostic techniques, including advanced ultrasound and genetic testing, allow for earlier detection of arthrogryposis, enabling timely counseling and management planning.
